_exec_summary.SummaryText:
9.Executive Summary 

9.1 Risk Management Program Approach



Red Star has multiple programs in place that address the Risk Management for this site. The facility's overall approach to chemical safety is an integral part of the risk management program and the safe "day-to- day" operation procedures implemented at the facility. The program is modeled after five elements functioning in a continuous cycle to ensure the safety of the facility and the surrounding communities. The Risk Management program model is comprised of the following elements.

1.    Risk Identification

2.    Risk Analysis

3.    Emergency Response & Planning

4.    Risk Monitoring & Control

5.    Continuous Improvement



Sherre-Ann Wallace, Program Manager, is the person responsible for RMP (part 68) implementation. The program manager may delegate certain tasks and responsibilities associated with the RMP to other facility employees as necessary. The responsibilities of the manager, or designee, include:

o    Conduct regular risk review for the facility

o    Review the status of all risk mitigation efforts

o    Identify and analyze any new risks

o    Identify steps to mitigate risks

o    Identify and rank most critical risks

o    Assess the exposure and probability for the risk

o    Maintain the project's risk list

o    Report risk status to necessary key individuals and stakeholders



9.1.1.    Risk Identification



During risk identification, potential sources of risk and potential risk events are developed. Each risk is then ranked or categorized, based on risk analysis. After identifying and categorizing the risk event, it is entered into the Risk Register. Risk identification is conducted at regularly defined intervals throughout the life of the facility and/or process. The known risks are identified immediately so proper response planning and monitoring can occur. All identified risks will be documented and entered into the Risk Register (an Excel spreadsheet), which is kept in a commonly accessible location. The Risk R

egister will be the ultimate source of tracking and documentation for all activities associated with the RMP.

 

9.1.2.    Risk Analysis



During risk analysis, the process will be reviewed and analyzed for potential threats that could result from failures and/or accidents in the process. The process will be reviewed and analyzed at regular intervals in conjunction with risk identification. The Risk Register will be updated, as necessary, to track additional potential risks as they are identified. During the risk analysis, the following information will be gathered and documented on the Risk Register:

1.    Potential Risk Event

2.    Probability of Occurrence (recorded as High-Medium-Low)

3.    Impact (recorded as High-Medium-Low)

4.    Trigger/Symptom - the risk trigger/symptom is the event that would need to happen in order for the potential outcome to occur. Risk triggers are usually expressed with some sort of qualifier. When the risk trigger/symptom occurs, the risk is no longer a risk, but has materialized into a problem/issue that needs resolution.

5.    Response (recorded as Avoid, Transfer, Mitigate, Accept, Other)

6.    Response/Mitigation/Contingency Plan



All identified risks will be documented and maintained on the Risk Register. Potential risks that currently exist at the facility/process that could result in a release of toxic chemicals include:

o    Equipment failures

o    Equipment leaks

o    Weather events - Tornado, Hurricane



9.1.3.    Emergency Response & Planning



When a risk is identified, the appropriate response is indicated for the risk. A customized mitigation and/or response plan is then developed and implemented to respond to the particular risk or emergency situation. The facility will function under SOP-920-SAF-191 Rev 3.0.    Further, the facility is covered under the Henry County EMA Emergency Response Plan.



9.1.4.    Risk Monitoring and Control



Risk monitoring and control tracks and evaluates the performance of risk- handling actions against establ

ished metrics throughout the life cycle of the facility/process. During risk monitoring and control, the risk register is reviewed for accuracy. At this time, any new or additional identified risks not included on the risk register will be added. Risk Monitoring and Control will be performed during the regularly scheduled risk review conducted by the RMP Manager and/or their designee. Documentation is an integral part of risk monitoring and control. Documentation will include

 

risk review dates, any changes to the risk register, etc. Each regularly scheduled risk review and all monitoring and control activities will be documented on the Risk Register. A revision date for any changes made to the Risk Register must be recorded under Revision History of the register. The revision history will record each time the plan is updated and revised.







9.2.    General Accidental Release Prevention Program

The facility implements measures, both technological and procedural, to ensure prevention of accidental release of regulated substances. Process controls have been designed into the process to prevent and/or minimize accidental releases of regulated substances. Regular monitoring and maintenance is performed on all equipment to ensure optimum operating conditions and minimize accidents.



9.3.    Five-Year Accident History

There has been no accidents in the last five year at this facility.



9.4.    Emergency Response Program

The facility has compiled an Emergency Response (ER) Plan, and has coordinated the ER plan with the Henry County EMA office. In the event of an accident, the Henry County EMA Emergency Response Plan would be activated.



9.5.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Continuous Improvement is an integral part of the RMP. This includes proactive planning and implementation of safety and process improvement ideas to further mitigate accidents at the facility. Along with the other aspects of the RMP, safety and process improvement ideas and plans will be revie

wed at the regularly scheduled risk review conducted by the RMP manager and/or his designee.

Each improvement will be documented in the Continuous Improvement section of the risk register with target implementation timing and responsibility. The progress of improvement idea implementation will also be reviewed during the risk review.
